results.title: Beginnings
results.creator_credit: Lina Gagnon, Suzanne Gervais, Clorinda Warny, Gason Sarault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film describes the animator’s personal view of the universe. Abstract landscapes evolve into strange, god-like figures whose images revert into landscapes. The movements are slow and dreamy. The product of an eclectic imagination, this universe draws on historical, literary, and classical sources to illustrate man’s close ties with nature. Awards: Eight including Ottawa; New York; Columbus; London; Los Angeles; Annecy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lina Gagnon, Suzanne Gervais, Clorinda Warny, Gason Sarault and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Before we ruled the earth
results.creator_credit: Pier De Lespinois, Bill Latka, Discovery Channel and Evergreen Films
results.brief_description: Using dramatic historical re-enactments and computer animation this documentary provides a fascinating insight into the world of prehistoric life and the eventual evolution of the human race from primitive Homo ergaster to Homo erectus, from the rise of the Neanderthals and the Pleistocene era of the Cro-Magnons, to the advanced sophistication of the Paleo-Indians. We see how humans battle to survive alongside such prehistoric predatory beasts as the sabretooth cat, woolly mammoths and gigantic bears in often extreme conditions where it truly is the “survival of the fittest”. Episode 1. Hunt or be hunted: Begins in prehistoric Africa 1.7 million years ago with Homo ergaster and fast-forwards a million years to Homo erectus through to the Cro-Magnons. Discusses the evolutionary process and the importance of adapting to climatic and environmental changes, of developing skills to master the art of survival and of how the discovery of fire-making played such an important role in the evolution story. Episode 2. Mastering the beasts: Follows the Cro-Magnons to America revealing their tenacity in surviving harsh elements, extreme hunger and the company of woolly mammoths. Also focuses on the Paleo-Indians of North America as two small bands come together for a ritual buffalo kill. Based on available scientific evidence, this interpretive program is highly recommended as an educational tool. Narrated by John Slattery, story by Brian Fagan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pier De Lespinois, Bill Latka, Discovery Channel and Evergreen Films

holdings.name: DVD; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows a family holiday to sunny Surfers Paradise, Queensland. The family visit the theme parks Ski Land and Marineland, which combined to become Sea World in 1972. The film features some great holiday footage of the motel pool, theme parks and the beach at Surfers Paradise, along with notable 70s fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 motel sign ‘Surfside 6: Holiday – Overnight’
00:00:19:00 kids playing in the motel pool
00:03:07:00 enjoying milkshakes and icy-poles
00:03:27:00 on a chairlift
00:04:35:00 water skiiers doing tricks at Ski Land
00:07:06:00 a pyramid of people on water skis carrying flags reading ‘Ski Land’
00:08:28:00 dolphins performing tricks in a pool at Marineland
00:09:33:00 a trainer and a girl in a bikini holding out a fish on a platform over the pool for a dolphin who leaps into the air; the trainer pushes the girl into the water
00:11:10:00 riding on three-person bikes called ‘Silly Cycles’
00:12:26:00 The Sands Hotel
00:13:53:00 rainbow lorikeets
00:14:30:00 riding on a toy train around the park grounds
00:15:00:00 boarding an ANSETT plane

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of the day to day workings of a country Victoria cinema –including black-and-white footage of the Mary Poppins premiere in Ballarat – and group sports in rural Victoria.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 black-and-white footage of Mary Poppins opening at Vegas 70 cinema Ballarat
00:00:45:00 glamorous woman arrives in car
00:01:50:00 the snack stand
00:03:58:00 kids blowing up balloons
00:04:20:00 crowds outside the cinema

results.title: Bedtime stories
results.creator_credit: Gerben Cath and International Video Books
results.brief_description: Introduces Dorothy Butler who passionately believes books should play a crucial role in children’s lives. Attempts to encourage children to read, by capitalising on their fascination with the television screen. Uses professional storytellers and well-known stories, giving fully annotated details for each book used.

Uses professional storytellers and well-known stories, giving fully annotated details for each book used.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Before night falls [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Julian Schnabel, Jon Kilik and Grandview Pictures
results.brief_description: Before night falls is Julian Schnabel’s second feature, his follow-up to “Basquiat”. The story of Cuban poet and writer Reinaldo Arenas, the screenplay is based on Arenas’ memoirs. The film opens with Arenas’ idyllic, if impoverished youth - brought up by his adoring mother and a dictatorial father who forbade his son’s poetry. A shift to the city exposes Arenas to urban influences and his teachers encourage his artistic expression. Openly gay and politically active, the adult Arenas finds himself persecuted by the Castro regime and his writing is smuggled to France in order to be published. Javier Bardem plays Arenas as a passionate, talented hedonist whose attempts to escape incarceration are both daring and foolhardy. The cinematography depicts Cuba as a magical and beautiful place, saturated in decaying splendour, which is crippled by corruption and state sanctioned police brutality. Schnabel employs an episodic structure to relay the key moments of Arenas’ life. Cuba - a place teeming with culture, food, love, sex and passion - is contrasted with Arenas’ ‘freedom’ in New York. Despite his liberation Arenas is depressed, living austerely and the scenes take on a bleached aesthetic, reflecting perhaps the writer’s longing for his rich homeland.

Despite his liberation Arenas is depressed, living austerely and the scenes take on a bleached aesthetic, reflecting perhaps the writer’s longing for his rich homeland.

holdings.name: DVD; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of Ballarat in the 1970s and notably the last day of tram service in the area.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:11:43:00 people using 16mm camera filming trams in Ballarat
00:12:50:00 people alighting the Lydiard st tram for the last time on 19 September 1971
00:16:10:00 conductor issuing tram tickets on the last day of tram service in Ballarat

results.title: Before It's Too Late - Teenage Suicide (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This important film can be used to teach students how to spot suicidal behaviour in their friends and it impresses upon them that they can actually save a life by being a supportive friend.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents surburban family life in country Victoria along with holiday footage in and around a developing Canberra in the 1950s. It includes some shots of the Prime Minister’s residence, The Lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 1940s women’s fashion
00:02:09:00 shot of a typical post-war suburban weatherboard home with car in the driveway
00:06:10:00 Christmas with children and their gifts and toys
00:16:10:00 shots from a military air show
00:20:33:00 shot of lounge room and television
00:24:13:00 aerial shots of Ballarat including the drive-in cinema
00:33:33:00 exterior footage of the Lodge and shot of Canberra developing
00:33:16:00 young girl using an old camera over looking a landscape
00:34:34:00 MLC building plaza and surrounds in Canberra
00:35:08:00 shot of old Parliament house
00:35:15:00 shot of the war memorial
